/0x22.title: 0x22 is an ambient music project
/0x22.text:
#### [Bandcamp](https://0x22.bandcamp.com)

Since 2015, after bands and instrumental music projects, [I](/karaman-hunor)'ve started composing electronical music. It started with making noises for a progressive metal album, but later I've found the long sine waves and fell in love with the ambient / drone sounding.

I'm inspired by feelings and the music of talented musicians like Nils Frahm, Celer or Ólafur Arnalds.

### Releases
[Metaphases](/0x22/metaphases) - 2017 December\
[glacio](/0x22/glacio) - 2017 December\
[With love from very small places](/0x22/with-love-from-very-small-places) - 2017 November\
[It was dawn when the old man died](/0x22/it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died) - 2017 October\
[Nothingness EP (early works under the moniker Shiip)](https://0x22.bandcamp.com/album/nothingness-ep) - 2017 February
/0x22.name: 0x22

/plore.title: Plore is an archive of travels in possible or impossible presents and futures.
/plore.name: plore

/p2p.title: Peer-to-Peer
/p2p.text:
These are the peer-to-peer projects I was/am working on in chronological order:

1. [ntain](/projects/ntain) ― Peer-to-Peer file sharing site → 2017
2. [orkl](/projects/orkl) ― Super simple peer-to-peer blogging site → 2018
3. [solo](/projects/solo) ― The simplest publication tool → 2018
4. [forkup](/projects/forkup) ― Updater for forked Beaker sites → 2018
5. [ridder](/projects/ridder) ― An RSS reader that you own → 2018
6. [seeder](/projects/seeder) ― Plug-and-play Raspberry Pi DAT seeder → 2018

---

If you're new to the peer-to-peer web check out:

1. [What does peer-to-peer mean?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peer-to-peer)
2. [Peer-to-Peer Day](https://peer-to-peer-web.com)
3. [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com)
4. [Guides by NCWG](https://guides.newcomputers.group)
5. [Secrets](https://lhs.nu/archive#dat)

---

Story: 

I've been attracted by the peer-to-peer web from a young age ― before I knew what it does mean. I remember standing next to a friend and sending a message to him over the internet (I think it was Facebook), when I realized how wrong it is that this message has to travel thousands of kilometers to arrive to him. 

Since then I'm planning and trying to built peer-to-peer networks, but then one day I've found the [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com) and [Dat](https://datproject.org).
/p2p.name: p2p

/writing.title: Writing
/writing.text: About tools, systems ― what I see, what I think.
/writing.name: writing

/projects/cereal.title: cereal
/projects/cereal.text:
#### [Github](https://github.com/kodedninja/cereal) [npm](https://www.npmjs.com/package/crl)

Cereal is an encryption scheme based on the AES256 symmetric algorithm.\
The keys never leave the two instances and they always change.

[More details](https://github.com/kodedninja/cereal)
/projects/cereal.name: cereal

/projects/datta.title: datta
/projects/datta.description: A readable plain text structure for strictly formatted data
/projects/datta.text:
#### [Github](http://github.com/kodedninja/datta) [npm](https://npmjs.com/packages/datta)
A readable plain text structure for strictly formatted data
### Installation

```npm i datta```

### Usage
[Documentation](http://github.com/kodedninja/datta)

### Structure
The header contains the names of the fields that are separated by **spaces**. The spaces define the max length of the value.

The ```---``` separates the header from the content.

The content forms columns (every field begins where its name is in the header). The last column is basically doesn't have defined length.
/projects/datta.name: datta

/projects/ff.title: ff
/projects/ff.text: **ff** was inspired from other functional css libraries ([Tachyons](https://tachyons.io) and more) and formed to the way I prefer it. I also took some code from them. *Thanks!*
/projects/ff.name: ff

/about.title: Hello, I'm Hunor Karamán.
/about.text:
#### [Github](https://github.com/kodedninja) [Twitter](https://twitter.com/kodedninja) [Rotonde](dat://81ff8011a4534aac2b46b7a82a6fce8afd0907b2ed0558d2dfb9e92888051e53/) [Are.na](https://www.are.na/hunor-karaman)

I work on experimental [tools and projects](/projects) that form a greater system: *life*. My main focus is designing and making functional tools / interfaces. I'm a true fan of peer-to-peer networking, functional design and the *[computer](https://newcomputers.group)*. 

Currently I'm making and researching tools for the [peer-to-peer web](/p2p).

Sometimes I [write](/writing) about the things I see or think.

 [0x22](/0x22) is my music project.

 You can visit the [Log](/log) for a consistently updating tracker of my productivity or read my [devlog](https://devlog-kodedninja.hashbase.io), where I write an entry every week to sum up my productive outcome.

> "I really enjoy making tools." - Callil Capuozzo

hunix94@gmail.com
/about.name: about

/projects/odot.title: odot
/projects/odot.text:
#### [Github](https://github.com/kodedninja/odot) [npm](https://www.npmjs.com/package/odotlist)

odot is a really simple checklist command line tool. It's pretty dumb, but I'll work on it. It makes todoing very comfortable through short commands.

#### Installation: ```npm install -g odotlist```

[Usage documentation](https://github.com/kodedninja/odot/blob/master/README.md)
/projects/odot.name: odot

/projects/forkup.title: forkup
/projects/forkup.text:
#### [Github](https://github.com/kodedninja/forkup) [npm](https://npmjs.com/package/forkup)

I was struggling with copy + pasting the ```bundle.js``` of my projects, when I made a few updates so I wrote this little module that updates local files to the upstream files if you (the site owner) want to.

It's included in [orkl](/projects/orkl) and in [solo](/projects/solo) too. You can update them by going to ```dat://[url]/update```.
/projects/forkup.name: forkup

This project is in a very early development stage and it's developed together with other guys in the [New Computer Working Group](https://newcomputers.group).

The documentation is on Github.
/projects/seeder.name: seeder

/0x22/it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died.title: It was dawn when the old man died
tracks: It was dawn when the old man died I.
It was dawn when the old man died II.
/0x22/it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died.text:
#### [Bandcamp](https://0x22.bandcamp.com/album/it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died)

At dawn warmer waves arrive to the surface of Earth. They break up into millions of other waves, then return into the atmosphere. These waves are the reason that life exists on Earth. These waves our the reason why we die.

"It was dawn when the old man died I." presents 3 perspectives of a dawn. Is just a simple dawn the same for a dying man, for a couple or for a child? Is it the same for you and me?

"It was dawn when the old man died II." is an experimental slowed down version of the first track. Doesn't sure which one describes more the concept.
/0x22/it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died.name: it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died

/0x22/with-love-from-very-small-places.text:
#### [Bandcamp](https://0x22.bandcamp.com/album/with-love-from-very-small-places)

In life sometimes we stuck into small places, places that make us feel closed and paralysed. Will a hand help you out from there?

"With love from very small places" is a concept album, written for my girlfriend for our anniversary. It's a journey to the surface from somewhere below. From a very small place.
/0x22/with-love-from-very-small-places.name: with-love-from-very-small-places

/writing/p2p-myself.title: Peer-to-peer myself
/writing/p2p-myself.excerpt: Since I've started digging into the peer-to-peer internet I wanted to move my site onto it. Today I found the way that perfectly fits into my workflow.
/writing/p2p-myself.text:
[![Peer-to-peer Day Image](/content/writing/p2p-myself/lines.png)](dat://peer-to-peer-web.com)

I've moved the site off of Github Pages and onto a combo of [now.sh](https://now.sh) and [Hashbase](https://hashbase.io). Finally I'm able to use magical subdomains of hex22.org on Dat.

### The core of the site: Enoki
[Enoki](https://enoki.site) is an "An experimental ~~platform~~ tool for peer-to-peer publishing" ― simply a CMS on the [Dat](https://dat-project.org) protocol.

The site was based on the pre-alpha version of it (a static-site generator with a CMS page) and I wasn't able to move it to the Beta version, because that's a "peer-to-peer first" tool. Today this changed too, because I rewrote it to use the Panel and I'm amazed by the feeling of it. It's the best writing / CMS tool I've ever used. Everything feels so natural and *in the flow*. Thumbs up, [Jon Kyle](https://jon-kyle.com).

### Hashbase
Hashbase is a seeding service by the developers of the [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com). Although peer-to-peer sites are powered by their users, it's good to have a constant peer. I try to use Hashbase as little as possible, because using for everything would break the peer-to-peer side of the sites. Also, I seed every Dat site I've visited and liked.

Currently I have a free account on Hashbase, but I'm on the edge of the 100 MB free limit. I'm planning to upgrade and have 15 GB of space. That's a lot!

### HTTP version
Command line tools have a warm place in my heart. That's why I've started using [now](https://now.sh) and used it for a few projects. More complex tasks are done in a few keystrokes (ie: buying domain names, DNS settings, SSL certs.).

The ```hex22.org``` domain was bought with *now* too. One thing I didn't know is that custom domains aren't supported in the OSS (free) plan. That's why until now the site was on Github Pages, but for the Dat URL I needed an ```https``` certificate.

Custom domains on Dat work like this: Beaker checks for a ```https://your-domain.com/.well-known/dat``` file and gets the raw dat URL from that.

Since my SSL certificate was valid only on ```now.sh``` servers I've decided to move the HTTP version to *now* and change my plan from OSS to On-Demand, which means I pay only for what I use. For a small project like this it's a very good price.

---

This means that currently I pay less than 2$ per month for this site, but when I upgrade my Hashbase plan there will be a **+7$/n** per month, where **n** is the number of projects hosted on Hashbase.

In the future I can do the same for subdomains for a +1.5$/domain.

### Inspirations
[How I publish taravancil.com](https://taravancil.com/blog/how-i-publish-taravancil-com/) by Tara Vancil\
[Distributed now](https://jon-kyle.com/entries/2017-08-01-distributed-now/) by Jon Kyle
/writing/p2p-myself.name: p2p-myself

/writing/later-here.title: Later, Here...
/writing/later-here.excerpt: Just a note about systems / tools I want to mention in later entries.
/writing/later-here.text:
Most of them are newcomers to my life, but they changed my workflow and day-to-day life significantly. Probably I forgot a few, but will edit this entry later.

It's also an all-around description of these tools and the reason I use them.

---

[Log](https://joshavanier.itch.io/log) was the first tool I've started using late last year. Inspired by [Devine](https://wiki.xxiivv.com) I wanted to write my own time-tracker, but then I've found Josh's and it was a perfect fit. I don't use it for prediction (yet), but mostly to review my productive output.

![Log screenshot](https://img.itch.zone/aW1hZ2UvMTg3ODI5LzEwMDM4ODQucG5n/original/Yvd0oU.png)

[Are.na](https://are.na). Oh, Are.na. It's one of the best tools I've found in my whole life. I'm not sure why, but I love it so much it's not describable. A perfect example of functional design. I'm very new there, but [I use it a lot](https://are.na/hunor-karaman/index). "Social media that helps you think"? Yes, please. My one-word description of Are.na is *quality*. Quality people, quality content, quality website.

![Are.na screenshot](/content/writing/later-here/arena-screenshot.png)

[Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com) is a bit different than the others, but I must write about it because it changed the way I think about the internet. I feel 100% better browsing on the peer-to-peer web, enjoying the beauty of 64 characters long urls, seeding and forking sites. Making personal tools based on it like [orkl](/projects/orkl) or [ntain](/projects/ntain). Or using what other people made like Dropout.

[Dropout](https://dropout.jon-kyle.com) is a tool that *"saves a url as static html/json for later offline access and personal archive"*. It was made by Jon Kyle, whose work inspire me a lot. Three tools from this list were made by him. He's a good guy. I mostly use Dropout to save documentations for offline access, as I try to reduce my internet usage.

![Dropout screenshot](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/33131061d30a2b6e36109cf7efc3797d84ffe3f0/687474703a2f2f64726f702e6a6f6e2d6b796c652e636f6d2f6d6f64756c65732f64726f706f75742d6265616b65722d322e706e67)

Another one from Jon. [Enoki](https://enoki.site) is *"an experimental ~~platform~~ tool for peer-to-peer publishing"*. It's basically a static-site generator with a simple CMS. Exactly what I was looking for. This site uses the "original" version ([enoki-starterkit](https://github.com/enokidotsite/starterkit)), but Jon's currently working on a new Enoki.

*Update: The site now uses the [Enoki Panel](https://panel.enoki.site).*

[Hardly Everything](https://hardlyeverything.com) is the last tool in the list that's by Jon. It supplies you with an "anti-feed". You can read more about it [here](https://github.com/jondashkyle/hardly-everything). The way I use it is that I save different sites and a set a "pace" for them. There are pages that I usually check too often, even if they have new content only once a while, so I put them into Hardly Everything and access them only from there. This isn't a rule, but I try to act like it would be. I'm much more organized, because in the morning I go through my feed and then I don't check them again for a day.\
(*Note: I've realized that I used the term "put them into" and it sounds a bit weird, but I do think about Hardly Everything as a grinder machine that destroys the low-quality time spent on these websites "unintentionally".*)

![Hardly Everything screeshot](/content/writing/later-here/hardly-everything.png)

I also want to write about how I use my phone. It has changed much in the past month. It's more ambient and less distracting.

> "Yeah, I think phones have failed us." - Edouerd Urcades

---
Update: I've came across Alex Singh's blog and found [this entry](https://alexsingh.svbtle.com/ambient-interventions-for-2018). He pretty much talks about the same tools as me, with better writing skills. I follow [Alex's channel](https://www.are.na/alex-singh/ambient-product-design) on Are.na and it makes me happy that he too is amazed by these tools.
/writing/later-here.name: later-here

[See more](https://github.com/kodedninja/microne)
/projects/microne.name: microne

/projects/notebook-index.title: Notebook Index
/projects/notebook-index.description: A public archive for scanned notebooks
/projects/notebook-index.text:
#### [Github](https://github.com/kodedninja/notebook-index) [Website](https://notebooks-kodedninja.hashbase.io)

Currently I'm collecting data to be archived here. If you have a notebook you would like to see, there's an [open Are.na channe](https://are.na/hunor-karaman/notebook-index)l for suggestions.
/projects/notebook-index.name: notebook-index

/projects/ntain.title: ntain
/projects/ntain.description: A peer-to-peer file sharing application based on Beaker
/projects/ntain.text:
#### [Github](https://github.com/kodedninja/ntain) [ntain](dat://ntain-kodedninja.hashbase.io)

Ntain was my first try in making a peer-to-peer application based on Beaker Browser. I love it's design, but it misses many functionalities.

You can use it by forking ```dat://ntain-kodedninja.hashbase.io``` in [Beaker](https://beakerbrowser.com).
/projects/ntain.name: ntain

/projects/orkl.title: orkl
/projects/orkl.text:
#### [Github](https://github.com/kodedninja/orkl) [Website](https://orkl-kodedninja.hashbase.io)

I wanted to build a peer-to-peer only blog; kind of like the p2p child of Svbtle and Telegra.ph. Fell in love with the idea of a site, which feels the same for the writer and the reader. The only difference is that the writer can change the content and the reader can't. Thanks to [Dat](https://datproject.org/), we can easily decide if a computer is the owner or not of a site.

orkl is also 100% dynamic, so it's basically just a bunch of ```txt``` files (using [smarkt](https://github.com/jondashkyle/smarkt)) = no site generation or building.

### Usage
The magic of Beaker Browser is the possibility to fork a site. To get started you can fork any orkl site, but for the sake of simplicity we will use an empty site I've made.

- Download [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com)
- Navigate to [dat://orkl-kodedninja.hashbase.io](dat://orkl-kodedninja.hashbase.io)
- Find the "Fork this site" button, click it and fill out with your information
- Navigate to your site
- Edit the site's dat.json, adding `"fallback_page": "index.html"`
- Read the "How to use orkl?" entry
/projects/orkl.name: orkl

/projects/pictogon.title: Pictogon
/projects/pictogon.text:
#### [Pictogon](https://pictogon.com)

Pictogon is a simple solution to make interactive images and embed them into webpages.

I've built the back-end and a part of the front-end editor. It's a small, yet functional tool and building it was an unforgettable experience. You think differently when you write code that thousands of people will use and you must be safe about payments and about a whole infrastructure.

I co-create it with Csaba, the creator of [Mapplic](http://www.mapplic.com), my good friend and mentor.
/projects/pictogon.name: pictogon

/projects/solo.title: solo
/projects/solo.text:
#### [Github](https://github.com/kodedninja/solo) [Website]()

Solo is a publishing tool based on the [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com) and the Dat protocol.

The main inspiration was [Telegra.ph](http://telegra.ph). Every entry is under a different Dat URL and there's no index page like on blogs or publishing platforms.

Only *disconnected texts* that centralize in the author's mind.

Solo is a simplified version of [orkl](/projects/orkl).
/projects/solo.name: solo

/projects/vocabulum.title: vocabulum
/projects/vocabulum.text:
#### [Github](https://github.com/kodedninja/vocabulum)

Vocabulum helps you build vocabularies (for constructed languages).
/projects/vocabulum.name: vocabulum

/projects/waves.title: waves
/projects/waves.text:
#### [Github](https://github.com/kodedninja/waves)

Its major goal is not to be fast, but to be more beautiful.

Inspired by Devine's [Shorthand](http://wiki.xxiivv.com/#Shorthand) and by existing shorthand systems, I developed my own. I'm a very fast writer, but I do write very ugly. With waves I want to change this: a bit slower, but more beautiful writing.

Waves written down looks like the waves of the sea (after a magical transformation).
/projects/waves.name: waves

/projects/ridder.title: ridder
/projects/ridder.description: An RSS reader that you own
/projects/ridder.text:
#### [Github](https://github.com/kodedninja/ridder) [Site](https://ridder-kodedninja.hashbase.io)

Ridder was made to make content reading transparent and controllable. It's an RSS reader completely owned and run by you, there's no server in the cloud to connect to.

There's no middleman to filter or track what you read.

Currently in pre-alpha.
/projects/ridder.name: ridder
